title: MODULE 9
description: Living with the legal system hanging over your head can be frustrating and feel hopeless. It can also be tough to see things from your supervisor’s perspective. This module discusses the intended function of community supervision and the importance of cooperating with your officer and the rules, even when you don’t want to. You will also learn strategies to help you work through conflicts with your supervisor.

pages.text:
Most counties, if not all, have a community corrections supervision department. You may know this as your probation or parole office. It can look a lot like a police department. Some supervision officers (also called Community Corrections Officers or CCOs, Probation Officers, Parole Officer, POs) may even have special uniformsor a badge.But,they have different responsibilities and prioritiesthan cops. In the same way that you have priorities and goals, community supervision officers make sure that released offenders (or supervisees) like you are choosing a law-abiding lifestyleand following the terms of theirsupervision. To do this, officers oversee caseloads of supervisees. You are just one person on what could be a very large caseload for yourassigned supervising officer. This meansthat, not only must your officer keep track of you and investigateany concerns he may haveabout you, but he must also do this for everyone else on hiscaseload. Supervisors may also have a role in assessing your treatment needs or even arrangingyour participation in treatment.To make all of these things happen, they spend their days driving around the community meeting their supervisees at their homes, work, treatment facilities,and at the supervision department office. They work hard to find resources such as free or low-cost mental health treatment, vouchers for identification cards,and bus passes.So, next time you see your officer and she’s a bit cranky, maybe cut her some slack!
The following is a sample job description for a Community Corrections Officers, according to the Society of Human Resource Management:
"To perform casework services in a designated area (such as probation/parole investigation, supervision and treatment; institutional treatment, custody and program operation; crime victim restitution; community referrals, court diversion programs; domestic relations and domestic abuse services; or other community corrections area) in order to carry out court orders, state correction directives or departmental programs for community corrections services; and to perform related duties assigned."
And some specific duties include (from www.correctionalofficer.org):
  • Regular interviews with offenders to monitor program progress and compliance
  • Administration of urinalysis drug screenings
  • In-home checkups on select occasions
  • Documented assessment of parole or probation subject for presentation to the court
  • Arrangement of community service hours to satisfy program requirements
  • Ensuring offender attendance at treatment, assessment or educational programs
  • Investigation of offenders suspected to be violating terms of parole or probation
  • Coordination with local law enforcement when violations occur
pages.subheader: Wearing Two Hats: The Role of Community Supervision Officers

pages.text:
Community Supervision officers are different from police officers and correctional officers in jail or prison because they wear two different hats. In other words, they have two different responsibilities that are both important, but do not always get along. Community supervision officers are responsible for helping their supervisee to get treatment and live a law-abiding life, and also enforce supervision rules and restrictions. This can get frustrating for you because one day your supervising officer may be signingyou up for treatment programs and helping you get your ID, and other days they may be drilling you with questions about your friends and why you don't have a job yet. Or pressing you to pay your fees. You will wish that they would just make up their mind,are they are on your side or not?!
Think of a time when you held conflicting responsibilities—when you had to do two things that felt opposite of each other. Here’s an example: it's hard to feel like a good parent when you have to work to support your kid, and don't have enough time to spend with them. Or, in your darker past, it was probably hard to steal from your parents so you could pay back a debt.
When you feel like your community supervision officer is on your case about work, who you spend time with, and other life choices, try to remember that they are wearing two big hats, and that both hats are necessary to help you be successful while also keeping the public safe. They want to help you meet your personal goals so you stay out of the courtroom for violation hearings or worse, behind bars.

fields.text: What two responsibilities have you had that felt opposite of each other?

pages.text:
Community Supervision Officers received a wide range of on the job training, including handcuffing, diffusing aggressive behavior, safe search and seizure practices, weapons identification, use of pepper spray, report writing, CPR and first aid, and even dealing with suicidal clients and those with mental illnesses. But, one thing is clear: Safety is always first. Staff is trained to keep themselves, community members, and supervisees safe from harm. Because their primary goal is to help you living a law-abiding life, they will do what they can to help you. The keyto unlocking those privileges is to first help yourself.However, they must also keep the public in mind, too.This is why they are strict with you about following rules and staying out of trouble.
If community supervision officers feel they, you, or another person are in danger, they have to do what it takes to keep people safe. This may include arresting you or another person, taking away regular items that may be used as a weapon (like kitchen knives or multi-use tools). They may carry guns and other equipment to use in emergency situations when someone’s life is in danger. Remember, safety is always first. Talking with you and working together to solve a problem is not an option when there is an immediate threat of violence.
pages.subheader: How are Community Supervision Officers Trained?

pages.text:
Not all supervising officers choose their career thinking they willhelp people who have a mental illness. But research shows that a large amount of people who are on community supervision also have a mental illnessor symptoms of a mental illness. Many probation offices are nowproviding extensive training to officers so they know how to best help people who have a mental illness while on supervision.
Some departments even have community supervision officers who only work with supervisees who have mental health needs (they may be part of a special mental health docket or court). These officers have more training in mental health and are taught to use a different set of problem-solving strategies with their supervisees than traditional community supervision departments. Specialized mental health officers and courts have a greater understanding about the resources in the community that can help people with mental illness. Rather than using probation violations and setting restrictions when supervisees are having difficulty, they try to first understand how mental illness may have played a role in their behavior. This helps people stay out of trouble when they are struggling to manage their mental illness.
But, this doesn’t mean mental health dockets are an easier road or that you will be cut any slack. Working with a supervising officer who specializes in mental health also comes with extra responsibility because they will expect you to work on improving your mental health, participate in treatment, stay sober, and take your medications as part of your supervision rules. And, you will have regular contact with the judge of the mental health court. In other words, you get more help, but you also have more eyes on you, and you can still get in trouble if you refuse to do these things! You can always help officers understand your problems by respectfully informing them about the symptoms of your specific mental illness or treatment needs and what you are doing to manage them. If you aren't sure whether you are part of a mental health court, ask your officer. You could also be on drug court, veterans court, or another specialized caseload.
pages.subheader: Do Supervision Officers Know About Mental Illness?

pages.text: Community supervisees are a tough group to deal with on a daily basis! People who have been in trouble with the lawtend to have long historiesof conflicts with authority and they see officersas part of “the man” or “the system.” They think their community supervising officer is“out to get them” or “screw them over.” This job isespecially hard when officers have to enforce lots of safety rules and probation restrictions because their supervisees on their caseload are not following the rules, being careless, or are being disrespectful. This takes away from the time and energy the officer could be spending helping their supervisees find new resources and giving them incentives for good behavior.

fields.text: How do you feel about your community supervision officer (be honest)?
What do you think your supervision officer thinks about you?

You may not realize it, but the fact is – your officer goes through a lot every day to keep you safe and help you be successful. Most officers truly are invested in your well-being and are rooting for you to do better. Imagine spending your day going to court, talking about how well your supervisees are doing, fighting for their privileges on supervision, and really caring about their success only to have them hate you, threaten you, and skip supervision visits because they think "I'll teach him to get in my business." When you don’t do what you’re supposed to do, your supervising officer then, by law, has to put more restrictions on, or maybe even violate, you. This can be disheartening for them when their supervisees were doing so well just the day before. And that’s all in one day's work!
There are so many different scenarios that officers find themselves in when supervisees don’t take their community supervision seriously and violate the rules. They may spend days trying to track down a supervisee who has stopped calling them, even going into to neighborhoods or other situations that are unsafe. What would you do in that situation? How would you feel when you left work each day? How long do you think you could last in a job like that? Supervising officers get tired of dealing with the tough decisions they have to make; it’s easy to get emotionally and physically exhausted. And it can feel like they’re working for someone who doesn’t even care about themselves.
People who work with offenders are at a high risk for extreme stress and negative feelings about their work, pushing a lot of supervising officers to quit their jobs early or to stay in their jobs for the wrong reasons. When supervision department are short-staffed, it can cause a lot of stress and stain across the department. And, as you know, stress can also cause significant health problems. This goes without mentioning the risk they already take on in their jobs, such as community violence or being attacked by supervisees who are not living a law-abiding life. Community supervising officers have spouses, children, parents, and friends who need them to be healthy outside of work.

pages.text: Think of your community supervision departmentas an organization, kind of like a business with bosses and workers. Businesses run best when everyone works together to solve problems. Take an example like the airline company, Southwest. Southwest is known worldwide for being a highly successful company because its employees are treated fairly and, in turn, they work very hard and take pride in the airline. And, the harder employees work, the more perks they get from the company. In this same way supervision departmentsalso run better when people are respectful and fair. To get this type of treatment, you must give it, too. You are more likely to have less stress while on supervisionif you simply follow the rules and don’t put up a fight when officers are trying to enforce the rules –they do this for everyone’s safety, including yours. The better-behavedyou are, the more privileges you will earn. Also, remember that officersoften do not make the rules and, just like you, they answer to a higher authority like their supervisors, the chief, judge, and government officials.
pages.subheader: Community Supervision Department as an Organization

pages.text: Sometimes we expect too much from other people. Our supervising officer tries to help us complete supervision –but at the end of the day, their job is to just keep people safe and keep you in check. It is easy to start expecting your officer to do extra things for you, like give you rides to the motor vehicle division office or to the bank. They may have even helped you out in this way before, but that doesn’t mean they have to every time you ask. They have their own busy lives.Rather than allowing yourself to get upset when your officer does not do extra things to help you, try to remind yourself that your relationship with your supervising officer is “strictly business.” This means that you don’t have to get along all of the time and neither of you have to do “favors” for the other. Think of your officer as like a shop keeper or store manager and you’re the customer. What kinds of behaviors make for good customer service? How do places of business expect their customers to behave? And what behaviors would make for a bad business transaction? Type the words in the appropriate box.

pages.text:
In our communities and neighborhoods, people usually see it as a cool thing to disrespect police and supervising officers and to disobey the rules. Model citizens are often seen as “weak” or a “kiss-ass.” The mindset is typically that officers are “on the other side” or represent “the system.” In other words, there is an “us vs. them” mentality that leads to conflicts and assaults on officers, not to mention a failure to follow rules of supervision. Some people take joy in harassing officers and like to play mind games to see how much stuff they can get away with. But, think about what happens when people mess with you? How do you respond? It’s harder to be nice, isn’t it? Officers are humans, too, so remember that when they are stressed and burnt out, they’re going to have a much harder time treating you nicely or granting privileges. When you’re denied privileges, you’re at risk for criminalness.
Think about the criminal thinking style of Power Orientation. Was this one of your common errors? If so, you may want to pay attention to how you interact with your supervising officer. Do you tend to undermine or undercut them? Talk down to them? Tell them that they are worthless, stupid, or a motherfucker? Do you like to argue with your supervising officer to gain control or privileges? These behaviors place you at high risk for disciplinary reports and even supervision violations, which could put you back in jail. Being in a tug of war with your officer, whose job is to help you, never ends well for anyone. You will either get in trouble or be seriously hurt.
It’s also important to remember that criminal attitudes are a risk factor for future crime. So, if you think things like, "officers are more corrupt than half their supervisees," then you are likely high on this risk factor. What do these thoughts do for you? Are they helpful? Usually not. Having a bad attitude toward authority decreases your desire to follow the rules, and not following the rules will land you in hot water. Try acting opposite to reverse some of your negative attitudes toward the people in positions to enforce the rules of the facility and keep everyone safe.
pages.subheader: The Nature of Officer-Supervisee Relations: It's (Not) Cool to Hate

pages.text:
At some point while on supervision, you will disagree with your supervising officer. Something he or she says will piss you off, upset you, annoying, or will be just plain stupid. You might disagree on supervision rules, curfew times, whether you are being truthful, or if your supervising officer is trying to screw you over. These disagreements are hard to solve because it’s your word over theirs, and you have a lot on the line: if you don’t keep your cool, your supervising officer could put more restrictions on you or even violate you!
So how do you keep your cool when you disagree with your supervising officer? Think back to Worksheet 4 Module 4, where you learned the Conflict Resolution Model. Hopefully you’ve been practicing this since then. How can you apply those five steps to resolving conflict with your supervising officer? Below are some additional conflict resolution skills that can help you resolve disagreements between you and your officer.
"I" statements begin with the word "I." In using "I" statements, you talk specifically about yourself, not the person with whom you disagree. Using sentences that focus on you instead of the other person will help you communicate how you feel and what you need without making the other person feel attacked or making you look like you are avoiding responsibility. Here is an example of a conflict and an "I" statement you could use to communicate your feelings and needs to your supervising officer:
Your old drug dealer surprised you at your apartment – he tells you he has a ton of business right now and is willing to pay you some big cash if you help him make a few deals tonight. He brought drugs into your apartment to show you everything he’s got. Then your supervising officer knocks on your door for a random visit. You open the door, and he sees who you’re with – and what he’s put on your kitchen table table-dark. Your officer grills you about who the friend is, and asks how you have been passing your urinalysis tests if you’ve been doing drugs this whole time.
How would this likely make you feel? Upset. My officer obviously does not trust me. He came in at a bad time and it's going to ruin my entire probation.
What would you need from the officer in this situation? I wish he would just calm the hell down so I can explain myself. I didn't even want this guy over.
Make an "I" statement that communicates your feelings and needs. It makes me upset that you think I have been faking my clean urinalysis tests. I need you to please be patient and allow me to explain the situation before we talk more. Can we do that?
You also want to be aware of your tone, even when using "I" statements. Make sure you are not coming across as sarcastic or defensive. Remain calm and state your need matter of factly.

Now, read the following scenarios and write how they would make you feel. What would you need from your officer in that situation? Then make an “I” statement that would help communicate and avoid the disagreement from blowing up.

fields.text: Scenario 1: During your last office visit, you left your wallet in the waiting room. By the time you realize it is missing and retrieve it, your wallet is picked clean – no identification card, no debit card, no bus pass. You have no way of getting home, and no way of buying groceries this weekend. You try to go back and talk to your officer to ask for help, but they won’t even open their office door. You know they’re in there, so you keep knocking. Finally, your officer flings the door open and demands what you need. You try explaining what happened, but they immediately tell you to figure it out, and that you should have been more responsible.
How would this make you feel?
What would you need from your officer in this situation?
Make an "I" statement that communicates your feelings and needs.

Scenario 2: While meeting with your officer for a scheduled visit, she tells you that because you haven’t found a job yet (and haven’t been paying your restitution because you have no money), you must appear in court to explain why. You can’t believe that she would do this to you – your officer knows you’ve been trying your best to get a job, so why are they punishing you like this? All you can think to do is call her a fucking bitch for not being on your side. Your officer tells you that you are disrespectful.
How would this make you feel?
What would you need from your officer in this situation?
Make an "I" statement that communicates your feelings and needs.

pages.text: Officers often feel divided between what their bosses want and what their superviseeswant. The head of the supervision departmentand the courts expectthat supervising officerswill show responsibility and leadership over the people on their caseload and that they will enforce all rules fairly. But, superviseesoften have the expectation that their supervising officerwill establish good relationships with themand always have their back.Because of their two different hats and these mixed expectations, many officers have a hard time keeping in good favor with their bosses and the supervisees they are helping. This can cause stress and conflict. Superviseessee an officer’s need to be responsible leaders as being at odds with their best interests(have you ever thought, “he won’t let me do this because he has something againstme”?). Supervising officersshould still be respectful and help you within their abilities, but they are not meant to be your friend. Understand that their jobs of safety and enforcing rules always come first.

While most officers want to see you succeed, there are certainly some bad apples. A very famous study back in the 1970s at Stanford University showed how easy it is for people to step into the role of superior and subordinate. The researchers in this study set up a fake prison in the basement of the psychology building and selected college students to play either a prison guard or a prisoner. Within days the study was stopped because the students started to take their roles too seriously – guards were abusing their power and prisoners were rebelling. (Keep in mind that these students were also not properly trained as correctional officers.) It quickly became an “us vs. them” environment. So, even ordinary people fall victim to this social divide that prisons and other places where people have different levels of power can create. Once the students were out of that study, they realized what they did was wrong.
So, what can YOU do if your supervising officer is too controlling, too authoritative, or likes to show off his/her power?

fields.text: How do you act toward people who abuse their power?

Many supervisees would resist orders, get in officers’ faces, spit on them, be assaultive, abandon their supervision responsibilities, or leave town never to be seen or heard from again—that is, until they get picked up on a supervision violation and sent back to jail. They think that if an officer is nasty to them, they should be nasty back. This may seem like it’s the fair thing to do. But, fair or not, fighting back will get you into trouble. For better or worse, officers have more on their side than you do. It’s like gambling in Las Vegas, the odds always favor the house. It’s not worth it, even if the officer is really a jerk. Here are some strategies that you are familiar with:
  • First, check to see what role you played in the situation. Are you resisting orders or did you give the officer some other reason to treat you the way you’ve been treated? Did your behavior deserve the actions of the officer? Remember that their role is to make sure safety comes first. If this is hard for you to think about, think for a moment how you would feel if the roles were reversed.
  • Use cognitive restructuring – for example, tell yourself that the officer’s behavior probably has nothing to do with you; she has a stressful job and this may be the way she knows how to cope with it. Think about the consequences of letting your anger get the best of you.
  • Use thought stopping – stop yourself from thinking about "getting even" or seeking revenge on the officer.
  • Act opposite – pretend to be polite and friendly, even if that’s not how you feel at the moment (but, make sure you don’t come off like a smartass!)
  • Use positive self-talk – tell yourself that you can handle the situation, the officer isn’t allowed to hurt you unless you pose a danger to him or another person; tell yourself that you have the ability to calm down and follow the officer’s instructions.
  • Use your conflict resolution skills – be assertive (but respectful) and try to talk to the officer about how her attitude toward you is making you feel or how it’s contributing to your stress or mental health symptoms. This may come as a surprise to staff because most supervisees won’t take the time to express their feelings.
  • Don’t react other than to do what you’re asked – sometimes people who seek power act like assholes to get a reaction from you (like fear or aggression), and when they no longer get a reaction, they stop. So, don’t react as if you’re scared or ready to fight; this may be what they want. Just follow the basic order you were given, whether it’s to do a drug test or wait in the hall while your officer speaks to his supervisor. They may be looking for a reason to violate you, but you don’t have to give them the satisfaction.
  • If an officer is truly targeting you, you may file a complaint with the department. Check what the procedures for doing this are at your community supervision office. But, try one of the other steps first. You don’t want to be the person who files complaints for every little thing.

Remember that most supervising officers are not like this. In fact, studies have shown that, even though the public and policy-makers strongly support punishment for people who have committed crimes, most staff in the criminal system, like correctional officers do not share this view and actually support rehabilitation and treatment programs for people in the system. Supervising officers are even expected to help you put your life back together as part of their job. So, in the end, they really are on your side!
